data.title: Predator (1987) — The Movie, Muscle & Masculinity
data.meta_description: 1987’s Predator might be the most perfect and visceral action-horror film ever made. I wouldn’t throw the word ”masterpiece” around lightly, but Predator’s right up there as one of my all-time…
data.text:
1987’s Predator might be the most perfect and visceral action-horror film ever made. I wouldn’t throw the word ”masterpiece” around lightly, but Predator’s right up there as one of my all-time favourites and it’s a classic benchmark of action filmmaking.

The film’s setting, cadence, and pacing are meticulously crafted, with each bit of dialogue, a sparkling gem. The setup is swift. The introductions are quick and the film travels the road of your typical action-adventure before segueing into a sci-fi horror-slasher featuring muscular action heroes instead of helpless high school heroines.

Predator not only stands at the apex of action movies but also cleverly deconstructs and subverts the genre, showcasing a film ahead of its time that only seems to improve with each viewing.

It’s a premise that started out as a joke. Executives pitching ideas for Stallone’s next villain suggested Rocky fight an alien which then became the basis of Predator.

What’s surprising is that on release, most critics dismissed Predator as just…
